trial_identification.studytitle: Sidekicks: Evaluation of a training program aimed at strengthening personal and interpersonal skills
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Sidekicks: Evaluation of a training program aimed at strengthening personal and interpersonal skills in university students

conditions.healthcondition: Healthy participants - community response to mental distress

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Studies of normal psychology, cognitive function and behaviour

interventions.interventions: 5 one hour (once per week) session training program targeting helping skills in response to friends/family in mental distress. Education in responding to low emotion, high anxiety, high stress. Education in responding to someone reporting suicidal thoughts. Education in responding to people who do not wish to seek help. Practice of empathic listening skills. The intervention will delivered by two clinical psychologists in a face to face group ranging from 20-50 students in each group. Monitoring of adherence is carried out by register of participant attendance at each session
interventions.comparator: Pre-Post Intervention; each member of the sample acts as their own control

primaryOutcome.outcome: SIRI-II The Suicide Intervention Response Inventory - this measures skills in responding to suicidal behaviour
Ryff scale of psychological well being (PR sub scale)

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Students of the University of Sydney
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Participants who the study investigators assess as having their mental well being compromised by participation in the workshop

trial_design.statisticalmethods:
Paired T-Test/ANOVA Mediation analysis
A prior pilot study (Sheehan, Stanton and Renner, 2016) examined results in the area of stigma change (SSOSH, SSRPH questionnaires) and self-reported confidence in helping others (on a likert scale) at pre and post intervention.
An analysis of statistical power was carried out using the differences in means and differences in standard deviations from that study. For the outcome variable of confidence in helping others a sample size of 15 is required (P=.05; power 80%) based on a prior effect size of Cohen's D=1.13. For the outcome variables of change in beliefs related to stigma, a sample size of 98 is required for the SSOSH measure (Cohen's D=0.28) and a sample size of 96 is required for the SSOSH measure (P=.05; power 80%; Cohen's D=0.29).

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Jane Foss Russell Building, Level 5 University of Sydney NSW 2006

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study aims to examine the efficacy of a training program at the University of Sydney. The training program is run each semester by the Counselling and Psychological Services. It aims to train students to respond effectively to situations where friends or family are experiencing emotional difficulties.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: University of Sydney Human Research Ethics Committee
